War workers pledge utmost production. Robert Shannon, President of RCA Manufacturing Company, Incorporated, left, presents William L. Batt, Vice President of War Production Board (WPB), right, with a book containing names of more than 20,000 employees of RCA who have pledged themselves to "beat the promise" on war production

War workers pledge utmost production. RCA workers pledge to "beat the promise" on war production. William L. Batt, Vice President of the War Production Board (WPB), right, presents a framed portrait of General MacArthur to Miss Ann Stankus, a Harrison, New Jersey RCA plant employee, who was recently given the Award of Individual Production Merit by the labor-management committee in the plant. Robert Shannon, RCA President, looks on. Miss Stankus' suggestion was to change a plate in small radio tubes, thereby enabling less skilled operators to increase output and improve quality of tubes for war use. She is twenty-nine years old and lives at 326 Johns Street, East Newark, New Jersey

War workers pledge utmost production. RCA workers pledge to "beat the promise" on war production. Miss Ann Stankus, a Harrison, New Jersey RCA plant employee, was recently given the Award for Individual Production Merit by the labor-management committee in the plant. Miss Stankus' suggestion was to change a plate in small radio tubes, thereby enabling less skilled operators to increase output and improve quality of tubes for war use. She is twenty-nine years old and lives at 326 Johns Street, East Newark, New Jersey

War workers pledge utmost production. RCA workers pledge to "beat the promise" on war production. Michael Straus, Chief of War Production Drive Headquarters, and Miss Ann Stankus, a Harrison, New Jersey, RCA plant employee look at a picture of Miss Stankus in the company publication. Miss Stankus was recently given the Award for Individual Production Merit by the labor-management committee in the plant. Her suggestion to change a plate in small radio tubes, enabled less skilled operators to increase output and improve quality of tubes for war use. She is twenty-nine years old and lives at 326 Johns Street, East Newark, New Jersey
Women's Policy Committee of the War Manpower Commission (WMC). Miss Margaret A. Hickey, Chairman, Women's Policy Committee of War Manpower Commission
Clouds

Production Executive Committee. First meeting of Production Executive Committee of the War Production Board (WPB). Charles E. Wilson, President of General Electric Company and WPB Vice Chairman of the Committee. Committee members, left to right: Rear Admiral Howard L. Vickery, Vice Chairman, U.S. Maritime Commission; Lieutenant General Brehon B. Somervell, Commanding General, Services of Supply, U.S. Army; Mr. Wilson; Vice Admiral Samuel M. Robinson, Director of Material and Procurement, U.S. Navy; and Major General Oliver P. Echols, Commanding General, Material Command Headquarters, Army, Air Force
Meeting on wartime economies for retailers, September 29, 1942. Left to right: R.A. Black, L.H. Harris, L. Henderson, J.M. Johnson, L.J. Ruskin, Walter Thompson
Meeting on wartime economies for retailers, September 29, 1942. Left to right: L. Henderson, J.M. Johnson, W.D. Hunnicutt, W.R. Thomas, Jr., R.A. Black, L.J. Ruskin
Meeting on wartime economies for retailers, September 29, 1942. Left to right: R.A. Black, L.H. Harris, L. Henderson, J.M. Johnson, L.J. Ruskin, Walter Thompson

Office of War Information poster (OWI). Poster distributed by the OWI to manufacturers, wholesalers, retailers, banks, liquor stores, taprooms, hotels, bars, beauty parlors, barber shops, war plants, American Legion posts, railways, bus and airline terminals, and government agencies. The original is 26 inches by 13 3/4 inches and is printed in red and black on white. Copies may be obtained from the Bureau of Public Inquiry, Office of War Information, 1400 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W., Washington, D.C.

America's leaders discuss war needs in a radio program. America's leaders discuss the Army-Navy Production Awards and the critical needs of war production in a program on August 9, 1942. Vice Chairman of the War Production Board (WPB) is in the foreground and Robert P. Patterson, Under Secretary of War, is in the right foreground. In the background are (left to right): James V. Forrestal, Under Secretary of Navy; Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information (OWI); and Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief if Staff of the Commander-in-Chief of the Army and Navy

America's leaders discuss war needs in a radio program. America's leaders discuss the Army-Navy Production Awards and the critical needs of war production in a program on August 9, 1942. Left to right: James V. Forrestal, Under Secretary of the Navy; Admiral William D. Leahy, Chief of Staff of the Commander-in-Chief of the Army and Navy; and Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information (OWI)

America's leaders discuss war needs in a radio program. America's leaders discuss the Army-Navy Production Awards and the critical needs of war production in a program on August 9, 1942. Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information (OWI), reads a message from the President in his first broadcast since he became the official spokesman for the government as Director of the Office of War Information

America's leaders discuss war needs in a radio program. America's leaders discuss the Army-Navy Production Awards and the critical needs of war production in a program on August 9, 1942. Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information (OWI), reads a message from the President in his first broadcast since he became the official spokesman for the government as Director of the Office of War Information

America's leaders discuss war needs in a radio program. America's leaders discuss the Army-Navy Production Awards and the critical needs of war production in a program on August 9, 1942. Admiral William D. Leahy appears on a radio program for the first time since he became Chief of Staff of the Commander-in-Chief of the Army and Navy

Victory Book Campaign. The Victory Book Campaign, January 5, 1943 through March 5, 1943, is designed to provide entertaining and instructive reading for our Army camps, Naval stations, Coast Guard stations, Merchant Marine libraries and United Service Organizations centers. The picture shows OWI (Office of War Information) Chief, Elmer Davis, contributing a book at the beginning of the campaign. Norman Cousins, editor of the Saturday Review of Literature and member of the National Campaign Board for the 1943 Victory Book Campaign, is accepting the book on behalf of the Board

Robert P. Patterson, the Undersecretary of War; John W. Studebaker, U.S. Commissioner of Education; the Honorable William A.M. Burden, Special Aviation Assistant to the Secretary of Commerce; Undersecretary of War; John W. Studebaker, U.S. Commissioner of Education; Honorable William A.M. Scene at the first broadcast announcing the formation of high school Victory Corps throughout the U.S. Broadcast was made over station WMAL, Washington, D.C. on September 25, 1942 from 8:30 to 9:00 p.m. EWT. John W. Studebaker, U.S. Commissioner of Education, places emblem on Paul V. McNutt, Chairman of the War Manpower Commission (WMC)

Willard E. Givens, Executive Secretary, National Education Association; John W. Studebaker, U.S. Commissioner of Education; Caption on print (cont.): Secretary, National Education Association (NEA), displays emblem to John W. Studebaker, U.S. Commissioner of Education
